channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Live: Covid-19 updates from New Zealand and around the world on 29 April
item.description: The Queen has spoken with Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern for an update on how New Zealanders are getting on in the midst of Covid-19. Follow RNZ's blog for the latest.

item.title: Victoria University considers 20% pay cuts due to Covid-19 losses
item.description: Victoria University is considering slashing staff pay by a fifth or moving them to a four-day week to help it cope with a forecast $50m drop in income, while Lincoln University is asking staff for a 5 percent pay cut.

item.title: Auckland schools to see high number of students return in level 3
item.description: The Education Ministry has been told 42,853 children will be returning to partially reopened schools and early learning services today.

item.title: Rural broadband network gets $15m investment
item.description: The government has allocated up to $15 million to improve rural broadband capacity.

item.title: Covid-19: What happened in New Zealand on 28 April
item.description: New Zealand moved down to alert level 3, with some businesses reopening, and restaurant takeaways brought hope to many looking for some respite from daily cooking.

item.title: Jargon to blame for confusion over Covid-19 'elimination' - PM
item.description: Director General of Health Ashley Bloomfield has had to walk back comments made by himself and the Prime Minister yesterday about the country having achieved elimination.

item.title: Charging students for accommodation could breach new law
item.description: New Zealand's student body president says university halls that are still charging students for accommodation could be in breach of a new law designed to protect them.

item.title: Fourteen arrests over theft of 112 rental vehicles
item.description: Fourteen people have been arrested and 50 vehicles have been recovered after 112 Jucy rental vehicles were stolen last week.

item.title: Back to work for fast food workers: 'Everyone was craving their Big Mac'
item.description: Staff at McDonald's in New Plymouth were braced for a rush this morning as NZers adjusted to Alert Level 3 in response to the Covid-19 pandemic - which for many meant a return to work.

item.title: As it happened: Covid-19 updates from NZ and around the world
item.description: New Zealand has moved into alert level three today, with more businesses opening and the number of new cases remaining low.

item.title: Red Cross fears for safety of refugees waiting to be resettled in NZ
item.description: Refugees waiting to be resettled in New Zealand live in danger, as they wait for borders to reopen, the Red Cross says.

item.title: Long winter ahead for Fiordland tourism operators
item.description: Fiordland tourism operators say they've been taking hit after hit since the end of last year, and they're not sure how many will be left standing.

item.title: Covid-19 latest update: Three new cases in NZ, no further deaths
item.description: There have been two new confirmed cases reported in New Zealand, and one new probable case, with no further deaths from the coronavirus.

item.title: New rest home case linked to Ruby Princess cluster
item.description: A Napier rest home worker has tested positive for coronavirus, despite having no symptoms.

item.title: Visa issues: Government delays 'playing with people's lives'
item.description: The immigration industry says officials are being hamstrung by the government in their efforts to sort out visa problems.

item.title: Young humpback whale spotted in Wellington Harbour
item.description: A young humpback whale has been spotted cruising through the Wellington Harbour this morning.

item.title: Govt announces new tools to assist job seekers
item.description: The government has launched a number of initiatives to provide extra support and resources for New Zealanders looking for work.

item.title: Covid-19 contact tracing app: National decries slow pace
item.description: Two weeks is too long to wait for a contact tracing app for Covid-19, the National Party says.
